Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Accelerating Digital Design Through Web-Accessible Anthropometric Data and Digital Human Models

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project is to quantify and predict the spatial requirements of humans of different populations and to understand how such requirements impact decision making for design engineering purposes. Current tools for the design of artifacts, tasks, and environments are hindered by the availability of detailed data on the body dimensions (anthropometry) for most user populations. To address this, research activities will be conducted in three primary areas: 1) estimating body size and shape for target user populations; 2) identifying relevant tasks, postures, and measures; and 3) creating a robust, scalable, and accurate human figure model that can embody the results, which will then be used for artifact design. The work will address the specific challenges posed by the secular trends observed in the U.S. population: the increased prevalence of obesity, the aging population, and changing demographics.

If successful, the results of this effort will provide, for the first time, freely available detailed estimates of the body size and shape of the U.S. civilian population and select global populations. These digital human models (and instructions on their use) will be made available online in an open-source format allowing their use in most commercial CAD packages. In addition to benefiting ergonomists and designers in a wide range of industries, over 1 million university students per year will have exposure to the work through the industry partner's existing university program (those using different CAD systems will have access through the open-source models). This will improve design education and facilitate accurate configuration of manufacturing facilities and product design - improving safety, performance, and customer satisfaction.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this work was to enable the improved design of products, tasks, and environments with which we interact. An understanding of body size and shape ("anthropometry") is critical to the performance of these designs in areas such as comfort and safety. Unfortunately, data on civilian populations--even for the United States--are not readily available. The best practice for obtaining this information is measuring a large number of individuals from the target user population. Since this can be expensive and logistically difficult, a number of methods for estimating the data exist. These are generally limited in their accuracy, a problem exacerbated by the increased prevalence of obesity and other global changes in factors affecting body size and shape (e.g., nutrition and healthcare).

This research made three key contributions to the body of knowledge. First, we identified 12 canonical measures that account for over 95% of the variability exhibited across individuals within a population. Second, we categorized postures and identified the most commonly referenced working postures. These were then defined using joint angles. Third, we created a number of new methods for synthesizing anthropometry. They are more accurate than existing methods and are applicable to a new range of situations. In particular, we are now able to consider demographically distinct populations for which only summary statistics. In effect, we are able to reverse-engineer data for an underlying population that will produce the published summary statistics. We are also able to overcome the non-normality present in most measures of breadth.

These three contributions have enabled the development of tools that are already being used in academia and industry. The www.dfhv.org website contains primers describing this and other efforts as well as best practices for incorporating the results. As a result of this GOALI project, the website also hosts over 50,000 models available for free download. The models utilize anthropometric data synthesized using the new approaches identified through this work. These were created in partnership with GOALI collaborator Siemens and using their Jack digital human modeling (DHM) technology. These models are representative of male and female civilian populations in a number of common postures. They are available in formats that allow them to be readily incorporated into CAD environments for assessment of candidate designs.

The synthesized data are also available for download as populations of large numbers (e.g., 2000) men and women. The data have also been incorporated into existing tools on the www.dfhv.org website, including the ability to explore relationships within the data and to conduct multivariate analysis.


Last Modified: 05/18/2016
Modified by: Matthew Parkinson
